reviewerName: God is a refuge for us (Psalms 62:8)
reviewText: I purchased and downloaded Mass Effect 3 (N7 Digital Deluxe Edition) from Origin. Origin had a 50% off sale that ended on 1/3/13. So, I got it for 20 bucks. Great deal. The digital deluxe edition from Origin includes the From Ashes DLC and the Extended Cut DLC [and a few other extras like art book, comic book, photos, soundtrack, mechdog, N7 hoodie (not interested in that stuff); and N7 arsenal pack]. Other free DLC that you can download separately from Origin includes Resurgence, Rebellion, Earth, and Retaliation.You can see all the negative reviews, and most of them focus on the ending.I played Mass Effect 1 and 2, and I imported my Shepard from Mass Effect 2. I enjoyed ME1 a lot, and liked ME2 as well (but thought some of the human characters in ME2 used too much foul language).After playing the game for a few days, I still had a long way to go (and that's a good thing). I think it's a lot of fun. After each mission, I've learned to visit with each of the crew on the Normandy (or when we dock at the Citadel), because they always have something additional to talk about (and that really adds to the story; some of this additional dialogue is funny/humorous...by design). Doing this means it will take me longer to get through the game, but that's okay...it's part of the fun...I highly recommend doing this. And sometimes when a conversation sounds like it's done and you walk away from the people (by going into a different room) and then come back to the same people, the conversation continues (an example of this is James and Garrus on the Normandy in the mess hall).The graphics, game play, and controls are all very good. It's like playing in a movie...very cool. The battles are intense. You can really immerse yourself into this game/series.There appears to be less foul language in ME3 than there was in ME2 (and I think that's a plus).I encountered one bug when I was talking to Jeff/Joker and EDI on the bridge of the Normandy; after speaking with them, Shepard couldn't move (he was stuck); this happened a couple of times; so I had to restart from the last save. Not a big deal, since I save frequently (and the game autosaves frequently too).OFFLINE PLAYThe game needs to go online to authenticate the first time you run it, but after that you can play the game offline (if you want to). Open Origin, go to the Origin menu, and select "go offline". Then, to get it to recognize that you're really offline, disable your network connection (you might be able to accomplish the same thing by unplugging your modem...I didn't try that). I'm normally online, but I tried it "offline" by disabling my network connection to see if it would work offline, and it did.OMEGA DLCI purchased this DLC, and played it today. Depending on how you play, it may take 3-5 hours to get through it. You leave the Normandy and its crew behind (along with the Reaper storyline). Instead, you accompany Aria on her ship and fight Cerberus on Omega, so Aria can have Omega back. In my opinion, it wasn't as fun as the main game, because your crew was left behind (and there was no Reaper plot). If you don't like Aria, then you might not want this DLC, because you see a lot of her. In the game, Omega is next to the Citadel (you join Aria's ship from there and it takes you to Omega).FROM ASHES DLCThis DLC came with the ME3 digital deluxe version, and I recommend it (so if you get the standard version, I recommend you buy this DLC). The mission is fun, and the Prothean character really adds to the story... not just during that particular missions, but throughout the game (and he is available as a squadmate).Going inside a Geth server was cool; it reminded me of scenes fromTRON: Evolution.Some reviewers said they thought the game was rushed to market, but I don't feel that's true at all. After 35 hours of play, I still had lots of missions to complete. And BioWare took the time to get the details right, especially all of the dialogue. Here is another example: On the Normandy on the crew quarters level across from the elevator, there is a memorial on the wall that lists crew members (or those who helped crew members) who died in battle; throughout the game, this list is updated as people die.WHAT ABOUT THE ENDING?Most of the bad reviews seem to be about the ending.After over 60 hours of play, I finally reached the end.  The last mission was very intense and well done.I do have the Extended Cut DLC; it came with the ME3 digital deluxe version.  If you bought the standard version of the game, this DLC is available free from EA/BioWare until April 12, 2014.  Since I played the game with this DLC, I can't comment on what the game would be like without it.  As a matter of fact, I couldn't tell when this DLC kicked-in, so it obviously fits perfectly into the story.There are 4 possible endings; and even within those endings, there are variations depending on your paragon/renegade choices.I played 3 of the 4 endings, and I wasn't disappointed.  Actually, with all the bad reviews about the endings, I was prepared for the worst; but instead, I was pleasantly surprised with each.The types of endings that are available to you depend on how you play the game.  Specifically, your effective military strength (EMS), which you can gauge in the war room (on deck 2 of the Normandy).  As/If you gain allies during the game, this adds to your "Total Military Strength", which is multiplied by a percentage known as "readiness rating".  Your readiness rating is 50%, but can be increased by playing multiplayer online.  The total military strength multiplied by the readiness rating is the "effective military strength"...your actual strength.So, someone who plays the game really fast...just to get to the ending...may not have the same ending options as someone who plays all of the side missions (and multiplayer) and has lots of effective military strength.Prior to playing the last mission, my readiness rating was 100%, my total military strength was 7514 (and my effective military strength was 7514).  So, I had all ending options available to me.  Also, my reputation was off the charts, and this also contributes to dialogue/ending options.To learn more (with spoilers), search for "Mass Effect Wiki", go to Games, Mass Effect 3, Missions, Plot Missions, Priority: Earth, and scroll down the page.  Priority Earth is the last mission.  The wiki discusses all 4 endings (and how they can be achieved).MULTIPLAYEREven after you finish playing the single player game, go back and play the multiplayer again...and again. It's a lot of fun even after finishing the single player game.  Multiplayer is team based.  It's you and up to 3 other people against one of 4 enemies: Geth, Cerberus, Collectors, or Reapers...you choose (or the leader of the game chooses).  There are several maps to choose from as well (and more if you download the free multiplayer DLC maps).  You can choose your character class (adept, soldier, engineer, infiltrator, sentinel, vanguard). Within each class, you can select your character.  Within each character, you build-up powers, weapons, gear. It's very organized and follows the same logic as the main/single player game. For a given mission, there are 11 waves of enemies (each wave gets a bit harder). During some of the waves, you have a team event to complete (like... escort a drone from one part of the map to the landing zone; or, hack a computer for a given time; or, activate several beacons; or, find the lost object and return it to the landing zone). The map graphics are great...take a moment to look around the map during the game to enjoy them! The voice acting is very well done and realistic. The game play is fun, balanced, and fair (I haven't noticed cheating). There are several difficulty ratings that you can select from (bronze, silver, gold, platinum). You start with few weapons, but as you complete successful missions, you get points that you can use to buy/unlock things like gear, weapons, characters, etc. It's a lot of fun to try-out the variations of characters and classes.  Very well done.CONCLUSIONI can say without hesitation that this series of 3 games is my favorite of all games to-date.It would have been even better without the strong language/profanity (especially taking God's name in vain), and same-sex romances.  The profanity is not excessive or gratuitous, but the game would have been better without it.  The same-sex romances (or any romances) can be avoided in the game, which is great; but I would rather that they not be present at all (just develop close friendships instead).I look forward to playing the series again in the future.  In my opinion, the game has high replay value (even if I know how it ends).  The game play, the controls, the story, the graphics, the sounds, the characters, the voice acting, and all the movie scenes are fantastic (and I look forward to experiencing them again).To-date, I have not found another game that comes close to Mass Effect.  It is very unique and well done.Also check-out the N7 HQ webpage, where you can monitor your "challenge" progress and review all of your multiplayer game statistics; go to: social dot bioware dot com / n7hqMass EffectMass Effect 2Mass Effect 3Mass Effect 3 Digital Deluxe Version [Download] (it includes 2 DLCs)Mass Effect TrilogyVisit my Amazon Collections to see my 4-star and 5-star PC games:http://www.amazon.com/gp/customers/A12LH2100CKQO/collections

This is better than I had expected.  I picked up the Day One edition, but since that won't be sold anymore outright, seems pointless to review on that one since they're identical other than the words on the controller and the code for the achievement.  I'd rather the review is useful on the one people will be buying moving forward.Well packaged.  MS is finally picking up some from Apple in how well they design the packaging and how they fit things into smaller spaces, like they did with the Surface.There was a 500MB or so update to run as soon as it was hooked up, which I did at work before I got this home.The initial setup was easy.  Since I have a gold Live account, I just told it who I was and away it went.  The only thing that threw me off was I had been used to the extra layer of security on the 360 so I had my "app password" all set to set this up, but apparently they did the security on the Xbox One so that if you're like me and have two level security enabled on your Live account, this doesn't need the app password but can use the actual Live account password, it just needed me to put in the additional verification code it texted to my phone.I got it home, and since I'm keeping my other Xboxes, I found a spot for this in my cabinet.  I have ATT Uverse, so I ran the Uverse box to the input here, and this to the receiver I use as my HDMI switcher as well as sound.I had spent time the past week trying to find things in google searches about whether or not it would use the HDMI to command the cable box or if I'd need some IR blaster, but hadn't found anything.  Fortunately, it's all HDMI.You specify your TV type, and it tests to make sure it can control it if the TV supports that via HDMI.  Same with a receiver and the cable box - it will try different controls until it succeeds and you say "Yep that worked."  Then it's set.The unit is nice and quiet.  I have five Xboxes in the house, although I'm giving the oldest one away since I don't need more than three 360's for what we use them for here.  The one I'm giving away is the original one from 2006, still running, never had a red ring of death, but sounds like an F-14 taking off from a carrier.  The Elite was quieter, the Slim quieter still, and last month I bought a new 360 E so I'd have a 360 still in warranty for a while since we need to keep one for all the games we have.  I thought that one was nice and quiet, but the XB One is even more silent.  It's so nice to NOT have all that fan noise even at idle.The Kinect is pretty amazing.  I've enjoyed the first generation one since its release with my now 10 year old son, and thought they did an amazing job with that, but this one just blows it away.  I like that I have Live accounts for both my son and I, and if I'm in the room when I turn on the xbox, it recognizes me and signs me in automatically (and you can enable/disable this feature BTW).  If he's the one it sees, it signs him in.  I tested with both of us there, and wanted to see if it would offer which one to sign in, but it simply signed us both in.  Impressive.Voice control - it's surprisingly effective for everything, my only irritation is with the guide.  That's where I dinged a star off of it.  Telling it who my provider was, my zip code, and it gave me a guide.  But I'm not a fan of the guide, it takes up way too much room, leaving you with a very narrow window of things to view as far as channel lineups.  I am looking to try to see if I can collapse it some, but so far I've had no luck.  But I'm expecting there will be several revamps over the next few months with updates and patches since this is all new release.My Harmony Touch remote works great with it, Logitech made sure they had the Xbox One as a device on launch day.Since I use multiple devices for my things, I don't just use the "xbox on" or "xbox off" to turn it on and off, but it's been spot on for my testing, it never fails to turn on or off via voice.  Navigating the menus with voice is just great, making things quick and easy to get to.  Watching TV could use a few more commands though, such as "channel up" and such.The controller is nice, feels great.  I always preferred the Xbox controller to the other consoles I have, and this one is a nice next version of it - comfortable, positive feeling on the buttons and triggers, not heavy.In the settings, there's a Kinect setting where you can click "what does Kinect see" and it changes through different view options.  The night vision is amazingly effective in a dark room.  I was impressed.The only game I have so far is Battlefield 4, and it's a thing of beauty.This does support surround sound for your cable box, but it's disabled by default, and turning it on under the settings it shows as "beta", since apparently they had a couple bugs with a couple specific cable boxes, but it works well for me with Uverse so far.I like the interface, easy to navigate and while some people think it's more cluttered, I actually think it's the opposite.  There's less things there to get at on the top level, which makes it more pleasant to navigate.The Kinect doesn't move at all like the old version did, and the cable is MUCH thicker.  Keep that in mind when you're figuring out where to place it.  For now I have it in front of my TV, and I've preordered an "above the TV mount" for it so it'll be up there next to the 360's Kinect and out of the way.Other than my dissatisfaction with the TV Guide and navigation of the guide with voice, I can't find anything at all that I felt disappointed about with this new system.  Blu Ray playing software was a free download from the store, and there's apparently a service for XB Live members to stream videos for free, something along the lines of what I get from Amazon with my Prime membership (which also ties in well here).I'm so fed up listening to the fan boys of each side argue about the PS4 vs. the XB One.  I have a PS3 but I have it for only two games, Little Big Planet and Infamous.  Everything else, I've always preferred to play on the Xbox or Wii, or now the Wii U.  I'm not worried about which has higher specs, since if someone REALLY is concerned about that, they'd be building their own high end gaming PC anyway that would blow both of these out of the water.  PS4 has some things better, but the XB One has some things that are better for me as well.  Both have their place, and hopefully both keep forcing the other to innovate.  The complaint about the Xbox being $100 more is offset when you get the camera setup for the PS4 and puts it right back at the same price anyway, so I don't care that the PS 4 cost less, because you GET less.  I'd expect to pay more when I get more.All told, this is just an amazing piece of technology.  I don't know if I'm going to leave the Uverse running through it or not, since I don't know how important it is that I control that via voice.  I don't watch that much TV, and most of what I watch I record and timeshift to watch later anyway, either for me or for my 10 year old.But in every respect, this is a solid hit.  Worth the money to me.

summary: A one of a kind next-gen jrpg.
reviewText: I only recently began playing this because I am not able to on my older model PS3(MGS4 bundle). There is a known issue with older 60-80gb models where it freezes right after the initial loading menu after the intro movie. So I had to use my brothers PS3 to play this. Be forewarned, this *is* a very real bug that will never be patched by Sega because they don't listen to anyones feedback. If you own any Slim model or most of the 40/120-160gb models, I'm almost 100% positive you'll be fine.Now for the review. This game has a severe learning curve. This is one of those rare games where the battle system is nearly as complicated as a chess match and sometimes as frustrating as playing a chess match with Deep Blue. You *need* to do the tutorials provided you in the Arena when you first start out or else follow an in-depth online battle guide or you will FAIL, and you will do so hard.Why am I making it sound like it's a game not even worth playing because it's so hard? Well, I'm actually trying to provide proof for why this specific JRPG deserves to be played more than most. Resonance of Fate has a very intrigueing world, some good characters, and a mediocre story. You most likely won't be talking about it after you beat it much though. The questing, adventuring, and rebuilding a dead world is what makes you want to play. You play the game in chapters(16 to be precise) and are given a story mission to complete for each before you're allowed to proceed to the next chapter. The game is linear in that way, but you can do a number of side-quests, a 500-battle deep Arena, and many dungeons to grind your level as much as your JRPG-loving(or hating) heart desires. In fact, most of this *needs* to be done. At the very least, you need to grind some levels to make the game easier. This isn't like Dragon Quest though. You can reasonably grind 10-20 levels for each character in less than an hour if you know what you're doing.Leveling in this game is quite novel actually. You don't gain levels by just winning battles, you do so by doing damage with certain weapon types(of which there are 3: Machineguns, Hand Guns, and Granades). The more damage you do to enemies around or higher than your level, the more experience you gain for that weapon type. As each type levels, you gain max health and the ability to carry heavier weapons and eventually even dual-wield guns making for some extreme damage potential later in the game. It's actually part of how you exploit the leveling system. Each of the three characters specializes in one of the three weapon types and by using their other, weaker types to level, you actually buff up your overall level. You effectively using the stunning weapon type, which is machine-guns, to make it so that the other two characters can just cause tons of damage on high level enemies and it buffs them up quite quickly.The combat system is much too vast for me to explain here, but I will say this. I played the game for nearly 20 hours before I finally got every aspect of it down pat. I can honestly say I'm as close to an expert on it as I'll ever likely want to be and it's made my life with this game so much the better for it. There are many ways to kills enemies, some you may never use at all. The farther you get in the game, however, the more choices begin to open up. Early on you are limited by how many Hero Actions you can do, but you get more things called Bezels in the game that effectively increase how many actions you can take without putting yourself at risk. This allows you to better make use of things like Tri-attacks. Without explaining any of those terms, just know that it's important to know what situation to use what abilities. You can't just go willy-nilly with this game and run straight at a monsters face with guns-a-blazin'. That's a sure fire way to get yourself dead. D-E-D dead. So dead you'll likelly wonder how much it would cost to ship this game back to Sega via Patriot Missle.I have to point out the importance of learning the system and the enjoyment/satisfaction you will attain from doing so though. It's a rare game that makes me want to learn its deepest and darkest secrets. It is amazing to me the balance though. You can(and will) become godlike by the end of the game, but most of the game is a fight for your life. By chapter 6 or so, I was doing fine and not having too much trouble, but later zones in the game always bring higher level foes that can do massive damage if you feel as though you can go back to slacking in your playstyle.It's just too bad the script and story plotting is done at such an average level. This world that the game resides in is fascinating and the characters are interesting. Sadly, the chapter structure that works so well for the gameplay design shoots the story in the foot because it's told in short and simple cutscenes sandwiching the beginning and end of each. It's not The Last Rebellion or Enchanted Arms bad mind you, but it isn't going to win you over like FFVII either.This game grew on me a great deal over the course of a couple of weeks. As I got better I began to realize how special the battle system is in a lot of ways. Very few jrpgs give you this level of depth(Demon Souls comes to mind and as much as people seem to want to hate it, FFXIII to a certain degree). For the asking price right now, it is more than worth purchasing and giving a chance if you're looking for a great next-gen jrpg. We have to take what we can get in that department right now anyhow.

description: Unreal Tournament 3 marks the return of the world's premiere first-person shooter debut on PlayStation 3 computer entertainment system. Unreal Tournament 3 unleashes the full power of Unreal Engine 3, taking graphics, gameplay, and challenge to a whole new level. Players engage in intense battles with other human players online, or against Unreal artificial intelligence that sets the industry standard. With the most powerful futuristic weapons and vehicles available, this is FPS action at its best!
reviewText: The Unreal Tournament series has been around for years.  Generally having a welcome home on PC's the third incarnation works on changing that.  Unreal Tournament 3 is a beautiful and fast paced shooter that has been perfectly ported over to the Playstation 3 console.From the very get go this game gives you several different options.  I want to cover all of these so you can become more familiar with what you want out of the game.  Many look at the Unreal Tournament as an online only style shooter.  I will tell you that it is much more than that.The game actually has a story based mode.  This is little less on the story and generally a great way to get people into the game and familiar with the game modes.  So if you are expecting an involved story you should probably go elsewhere.  You get all the difficulty settings from casual to very hard.  For someone like me who has never played Unreal Tournament I played casual to get more familiar with the game.  One thing I can say after playing the story for several hours it is not simple on any level.  The A.I. is actually excellent giving me more of a challenge than I ever expected.Next the game has instant action where you can go from death match to team death match and the other true favorites like capture the flag.  There are other game types available also.  This instant action is played against the bots who provide plenty of competition.  This is also another great way to improve your skills before you take on the real competition.Now is the most interesting part and that is the online.  This game provides an almost seamless online experience as you can take on 15 others in some matches.  What keeps this game fresh is the incredible amount of maps that never get old.  The game modes also provide for frantic fun.  The game play is incredibly fast paced which is unlike any shooter I have ever played.If you are looking for a fun sci-fi shooter that is non-stop action then Unreal Tournament 3 should be up your ally.  This game has been done perfectly on the PS3.  From the incredible graphics to the amazingly quick game play.  It's hard not to get addicted to the fun in this game.  Shooter fans this game is well worth at least a look if not a purchase.

reviewText: I did not like the game, I am not an "Online Gamer". I was expecting a game kind of "Resistance: Fall of man" in the campain mode, but it is basically a preparation for the online action, steal the flag, destroy enemies' "Power generators" etc. To me, that is painfully boring, but that is my personal opinion. I changed the almost new game for Assasin Creed and now I am having a blast.

You may note that you also get the stereo headset adapter with the Turtle Beach XO gaming headphones. This part is actually made by Microsoft itself and comes in at quite a chunk of change on its own.,So if you remove that costing, these natty stereo cans are quite reasonably priced.At the time of writing I'm still not 100% sure if the xbox one is outputting true 5.1 surround yet and if it is, is it passing it through the controller? My gut says no, but then I still use my 360 more than the one so perhaps I haven't spent enough time with my shiny new toy.Set up is super easy and once you've updated everything you simply plug the adapter into your controller and the phones into the adapter. You're now ready to play and frankly this is a great, simple way to have wireless sound.Audio wise things are what you'd expect from a sub $100 set of headphones - more like sub fifty dollars if you subtract the standalone cost of the adapter. Will you be blown away? Possibly not. But for most of us the sound is perfectly fine and certainly preferable to in TV speakers.They fit snug as others have mentioned but nothing too terribly tight even in gaming marathons. The microphone isn't adjustable per se but can be removed. There's also no in ear chat monitoring which means you won't hear your voice as you speak. Again this is caused by Microsoft's decisions and not something Turtle Beach can fix.For the price this is a very inexpensive entry level set of great-sounding cans that are super easy to connect and do what's claimed on the box. Recommended.

description: Neverwinter Nights 2 returns you to the Forgotten Realms, one of the popular campaign settings of Dungeons and Dragons. Emerge from the tiniest of villages into a sweeping tale of danger and war, chronicling your rise from a peasant to a full-fledged hero of the Realms. The story takes place several years after the original Neverwinter Nights, and reintroduces popular characters and NPCs in a new storyline with new challenges.
reviewText: This is one of my favorite rpgs and is my favorite D&D; rpg. This game features a nice immersive storyline and exceptional party characters, with their own personalities, strengths and weaknesses. Characters will argue with you or each other, leave or turn on you based on your actions, and some may die. You have a number of choices to make and can leans towards good or evil, or somewhere in between.The storyline is pretty good, though the ending is a bit short and disappointing. The biggest con is the automatic fighting, which 1st person shooter fans may not like, but as this is an rpg, I don't mind it at all. The graphics are good, but camera control can be difficult which often forces you to do a birds eye view which takes away from the graphics.This is a long game, but one I enjoyed playing through multiple times. I didn't care for the crafting system, but there is plenty of treasure and items to find or buy.

summary: More of the old, little of the new...
reviewText: With all honesty I can't say I was disappointed as I knew it would fall pretty flat. Not to say that Black Ops II is a bad game, because it isn't its very decent. The single player experience was pretty stale, it was pretty much the same thing I saw in Black Ops 1 and Modern Warfare 3. The main story was pretty short, and despite all the hooplah about important choices effecting the outcome they really didn't. Other than a few dialogue changes. One thing that seemed better though was that it felt like they finally put a cap on the infinite re-spawning enemies. While the story and voice acting are definitely good there are still some very tongue in cheek kind of moments. (Spoilers!) Like charging a double barreled tank on horseback??? really? Another bit that left much to be desired were the side missions with the main story. While I could see that the developers really tried to mesh in a real time strategy feel to it in the end you'll find yourself running and gunning as you would usually do.The multiplayer was pretty much the same experience I've seen in past Call of Duty titles. With the most frustrating return being bad maps. All maps feel claustrophobic which really effects the overall game play. Instead of using teamwork and strategy to win the day, your reduced to camping or running around constantly only to hope that you come across someone while their backs are turned. The weapons load-out though has some nice new touches. Such as the ability to use more perks or add more attachments to your weapons. With that the leveling is pretty much the same as it was in Black Ops I. As you level higher you unlock more camo, weapons, care packages and so on. One thing that I really liked though was the ability to customize your own in-game gamertag. I've seen some very creative stuff while online. In the end is seems they did everything good, except the maps for multiplayer.In the end it reach the hype around it and left me unsatisfied. The Zombies bit of the game offered the most fun for me, but wasn't enough to make me like it more. Perhaps next time we'll see something better.
I DON'T HAVE WORDS TO TALK ABOUT THIS GAME, IT'S SIMPLY AWESOME IN EVERY ASPECT, FROM THE GRAPHICS TO THE PACKAGE, A MASTERPIECE FROM HIDEO KOJIMA !!!!!!!!

Golden Abyss combines the setting and feel of the first game, Drake's Fortune, then sprinkles in some polish seen in the second game, Among Thieves. Similar to Drake's Fortune, Golden Abyss is more scaled back when it comes to set piece level design and opts for something a little more restrained. However, do not take this as a fault, as Golden Abyss is quite frankly one of the most enjoyable Uncharted adventures to date.It's not developed by Naughty Dog, but it is developed by Sony Bend, who proved their game development mastery with games such as Resistance Retribution, Syphon Filter: Dark Mirror, Syphon Filter: Logan's Shadow, etc. Sony Bend is more than capable of delivering a full-on Uncharted experience in handheld form, and Golden Abyss is all the proof you need.This is a phenomenal Uncharted game brought to a handheld with wonderful graphics, witty and interesting storytelling, good characters, nice gameplay, etc. If you're an Uncharted fan and want to know the events before Drake's Fortune, buy Golden Abyss and I think you'll be very satisfied with what you're getting.

summary: Surely, THE Game of this Console Generation.
reviewText: What is there to be said that has not already been discussed about Rockstar Games newest addition to the library; Grand Theft Auto V? Everything you saw from the first game play teaser to the last TV spot are all true. What you see is what you get, and then some. The fifth installment to the notorious Grand Theft Auto series delivered so many goods on so many spots that it's almost unbelievable to say this game is almost near video game perfection. If nothing else, it's a technological achievement and already a worthy game of the year winner.The setting is the much loved revisited San Andreas area that has increased tenfold with beautiful HD visual flair. The player will notice immediately that the game is brighter, more attractive, and varied compared to GTA IV's Liberty City. Within the sprawling and busy streets of Los Santos to the more desert ridden towns surrounding the Alamo Sea, to the mountainous outskirts of Vinewood Hills, there is so much detail presented that sometimes I had to sit still and watch the interaction between the game's AI and the environment. It's as if Rockstar literally took pictures of Los Angeles and California and just focused on recreating what they saw in every possible way. There is even an underwater environment marking a first for the GTA series and I think Rockstar Games!New to the GTA franchise is the ability to play not only as one criminal protagonist, but three. A new character swap feature is introduced allowing the player to switch on the fly (sometimes respectfully situational) while playing the single player story mode. Not only did Rockstar create three different personalities, but settings for each one as well. Michael is a retired thief under witness protection who is trying to deal with his extremely dysfunctional family. Franklin is a common thug from the streets who befriends Michael in hopes of earning better scores instead of just being a gang hustler. Trevor is a past associate of Michael's where a heist went wrong...and he's a complete psychopath. All three are a treat to play as seeing and hearing their perspectives while running around in San Andreas. While you are playing as one character, the other two will be doing something completely different. For example, while doing a solo mission with Franklin, Michael might be dropping his wife off at a mall, while Trevor is throwing somebody off a bridge into oncoming traffic. Instead of the same rinse and repeat cut scenes, Rockstar actually took the time to make switching between characters entertaining. Trevor being the most notorious, you'll never know what they might be doing at that moment. This actually helped keep the single player from ever being dull. When playing through the game, I couldn't help but want to see the three different perspectives while on missions. Also new to the franchise are the heist mechanics. GTA V's mission structure will seem linear to many, but it's these  crime movie/tv inspired moments where the single player shines.  You are able to select from two missions paths and select who you want on your crew for various jobs. Go in on a jewel store robbery aggressively, or choose the subtle approach and subdue everybody inside with knockout gas. Adding to the experience are a vast amount of side missions and activities for these three to partake. Tennis, darts, races, biking, target practice, stock exchanging, property management, assassinations, bar hopping, in game TV/movie watching, car customization, to name a few.Animations and textures are vastly improved with Rockstar's Euphoria engine. Characters feel more realistic making each one you encounter unique from each other. For an open world game, the motion capture and immense variety of dialogue presented here is phenomenally detailed. Even during mission cut scenes I could not take my eyes and ears off the action and character interactions. A fair warning for those who are sensitive to vulgar dialogue, intense violence, and gratuitous nudity: there is a plentiful amount here that staples GTA V's M rating. This is no way a game to be played for the immature crowd. Do everybody a favor and be mindful when playing this game. Also, don't be that jerk who would buy this for kids. GRAND THEFT AUTO V IS A GAME FOR ADULTS.One of the strong suits GTA V utilizes for game play's sake is the conglomeration of the past Rockstar games. Driving vehicles is arguably improved upon and feels like you are playing Midnight Club rather than dealing with a "realistic" but aggravating approach much like how GTA IV intended. I'll admit it felt a bit "arcadey" at first, but I immediately welcomed this change as I was actually driving to my destinations without crashing into everything accidentally (Don't worry, traffic can be unpredictable as I still have random crashes. Some intentional). The shooting/aim, cover, and weapon wheel system, respectfully inspired from Max Payne 3 and Red Dead Redemption, allow you to control and select weapons faster and strategically during any fire fight. The auto-aim feature returns (you can turn it off) and is less stingey from GTA IV. Also surfacing from Red Dead Redemption is the Strangers and Freaks interactions. While touring around San Andreas, you can randomly meet people that have simple requests for your to perform which can actually effect the game for that character permanently. Help two store robbers with a getaway and you might be able to add them to your future heist crew. Get a rich guy to the airport on time, and he could give you insight on what is a good stock option.Of course, there are limitations keeping GTA V from being that perfect crime open world game. Heists are very few. You'll wish Rockstar packed a few more in so your characters could earn more money when needed. Some of the strangers and freaks situations can happen at the wrong time, let's say while you are already being chased by the cops. Speaking of the police, THEY ARE RELENTLESS in this game. A two star chase could turn into a 3 star one where simply getting away from police  helicopters can be aggravating instead of engaging. Although the radio stations do provide a good amount of variety, I found that not having the player custom made music station an opportunity missed. It worked well with GTA IV's PC port. Speaking of radio stations, sorry Heavy Metal fans, there is none here...for some reason. Some of the vast open world parts, although still detailed, can seem barren with nothing to do except drive and run around. I wished some of the mission paths lead to these parts so the every area in the game is utilized fully. Near the end, I thought one of the character's dialogue focuses became redundant, wishing he would just move on. Also, (SLIGHT SPOILER) I wasn't too keen that about having the decision when deciding the fate of my characters. Since the game was designed for these three to run rampant on San Andreas, why would you want to kill off one of them? Don't' worry, there is another choice which I think the majority of GTA V players went with. It's nice to have a choice for three possible endings, but I think it really wasn't needed here.Regardless of the nitpicky things I could point out while playing GTA V, I immediately forgot and forgave and found something else to attract my attention to while in game. There is so much to do for a single player game. I clocked my single player story play through at 44 hours with side activities and missions I have yet to finish and continue for my end game portion. For $59.99 and that amount of time I spent playing, I can't help but feel I got a better deal here than I ever did with any of the Mass Effect games and Saint's Row the Third. The best part, the multiplayer portion, Grand Theft Auto Online, is not even out yet (All owners of GTA 5 receive this free of charge, will be released October 1st, may come back and add to review). Grand Theft Auto V has become literally what I call the official example of what to expect from future open world games. Do yourself a favor, if you are of mature mind who loves crime dramas and a time consuming open world game to play in, pick this title up. Whatever price this game will be when you do, it will be worth every penny spent. You'll be wanting to come back for more.****UPDATED 10/1/2013 Online Review still in progress:Well, I still could not connect, but I was able to do a solo session just to see the intro and be able to run around. However, you can't do anything mission related. You can get money and XP, but you have to kill/steal and lose the cops.However, here is what is really hurting my liking of it so far:Character customization is an absolute joke. Now I know Rockstar's history of these for open world games haven't been the best, but you would think they would at least try to compete against Saint's Row on this front. I'm not talking about super detailed because the gameplay is what matters most, but here, I don't think you will get the character looks YOU want. IV's customization was limited, but here it's a strange story. I felt that to only really get somebody that looks different was to spam the random button till something looked okay. I have John Marsten as a father, but the grandma and grandpa selection to change how you look was stupid. The whole heritage thing, is finicky and restrictive. The lifestyle, I don't understand. Because if you put more in one category, it can change how you look. Like a random huge sun hat because you lounge or something. Overall, it's a strange system to me.I think they made in game options worse now. When in Game, the start button is completely disabled. which you think would be the way to press start to see the whole map, then to see if your friends are online regardless if they are playing GTA V or not, then invite them that way. At least when you used your phone in a multiplayer game, you saw your contacts via XBlive anyway.

description: Drivers, start your engines!Nintendo is bringing Mario and his friends with their finely tuned racing machines back and this time to the Nintendo Wii. With 3 different control styles and a Wii Wheel included in the box,Mario Kart Wiiis bound to be the best in the series. The worldwide race is on with a whole new set of tricks, tracks, and ways to play! Place first in Grand Prix circuits or clear skill-based missions.Mario Kart Wiidraws on courses and battle arenas from every game in the series ? not to mention tons of new ones ? the true king of the Mushroom Kingdom racing circuits will finally be crowned.Wii Wheel Included!New Intense Tracks and TricksView larger.Cool new car designsView larger.Mario and his friends are back and ready to race once again inMario Kart Wii! Experience new tracks, enhanced Wii graphics, extraordinary gameplay and much more! Place first in Grand Prix circuits or clear skill-based missions to open up increasingly difficult and thrilling circuits. Players can have multiplayer races on any open courses or battle in arenas. Also included withMario Kart Wiiis the Wii Wheel! Now you can feel like your Mario and steering to avoid obstacles and doing incredible stunts - in the safety of your home of course.Game Features:The Wii Wheel transforms the Wii Remote™ controller into a steering wheel that feels natural in anyone's hands, while the Wii Remote and Nunchuk™ controller offer a classic control style for theMario Kartveteran. In either configuration, players can perform speed-boosting tricks with a shake of the Wii Remote.Players can race as their favorite Nintendo character, or even as themselves!Mario Kart Wiilets players race with their personalized Mii™ characters. And racers will see other Mii characters they have created cheering from the sidelines on some race courses.Players can compete with up to three friends in their living room. Or challenge up to 11 opponents via Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection in the biggestMario Kartrace yet. All tracks and modes of play are available via Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection, and players can visit theMario KartChannel to compete in tournaments, check rankings, see when their friends are playing and download ghost data.Cruise new tracks and arenas or tour classic courses fromSuper Mario Kart™, Mario Kart® 64, Mario Kart®: Super Circuit™, Mario Kart®: Double Dash!!™andMario Kart® DS. Tired of riding on four wheels? Bust out one of the new motorbikes for special tricks and techniques.CharactersNintendo favorites Mario™, Luigi™, Peach™, Yoshi®, Donkey Kong®, Wario™, Bowser™ and Toad™, plus a host of new faces-including your own! Get into the game and put your Mii™ character behind the wheel.Special Powers/Weapons/Moves/FeaturesWhether racing around an obstacle-filled track or battling in an arena, drifting and tossing items are the keys toMario Kartsuccess. Players can shake the Wii Remote while launching off a ramp to pull off a trick that will temporarily boost their speed. When riding a bike, players can gain additional speed by flicking the Wii Remote up and popping a wheelieNintendo Wi-Fi Connection:Keeping in the tradition ofMario Kart, Nintendo has pushed multiplayer racingeven further utilizing the Wii's built in Wi-Fi Connection. There are two options for races and battles over Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection: up to 12 people via Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection or up to 10 people via Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection with two people playing locally.
reviewText: To be honest I was sceptical about getting this game and thought about maybe not getting it.  That would have been terrible!!  This game is so much fun to play and I wouldn't play it any other way than with the Wii Wheel that comes with it.  We bought an extra wheel so we could both use it.This game does not disappoint in the fun factor!  From the start of the race until the finish you will have so much fun.  It took about 10-15 minutes to get used to the wheel, but after that its been wonderful.  The levels are a blast and its really cool that they have brought levels back from pretty much every Mario Kart version (SNES, 64, GBA, DS).I tested it out last night online and it was a whole new game playing against people from all over the world.  It shows you where each player is from before the race starts, so its cool to see you are playing with people from the UK, Canada, Asia, and others.  I didn't experience any lag in the 2 or more hours that I've played online.My Score:Graphics - 4.5Audio - 5Replay - 5Fun - 5Controls - 5

description: Call the shots in epic battles all over the world and expand your realm of influence throughout the tumultuous eighteenth century with Empire: Total War for your PC. Set against the bold intellectual landscape of the Enlightenment, this extension of the Total War franchise brings you out of the middle ages and into a realm where guns, gunpowder, and naval warfare have a dramatic influence on the face of combat..caption { font-family: Verdana, Helvetica neue, Arial, serif; font-size: 10px; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic; } ul.indent { list-style: inside disc; text-indent: -15px; } table.callout { font-family: verdana; font-size: 11px; line-height: 1. 3em; } td.vgoverview { height: 125px; background: #9DC4D8 url(http://images.amazon.com/images/G/01/electronics/detail-page/callout-bg.png) repeat-x; border-left: 1px solid #999999; border-right: 1px solid #999999; padding-left: 20px; padding-right: 20px; padding-bottom: 10px; width: 250px; font-family: verdana; font-size: 12px; } img.withlink {border:1px #777777 solid;}Realistic landscapes and weather add drama to your campaigns.View larger.Dynamic, 3D naval warfare expands the combat zone.View larger.For the first time, North America is open as a field of battle.View larger.Ships boast destructible sails.View larger.Historic Factions, Expanded Horizons, and an Updated Campaign MapTotal War's detailed, turn-based battle system has received some serious upgrades that will have an impact on both seasoned commanders and newly minted combatants. The UI has been streamlined, and the systems for handling trade and diplomacy have been updated. You have improved advisors at your disposal, and realistic espionage techniques can be carried out using agents.Empire puts a variety of major political factions into your hands, including France, Spain, Great Britain, Sweden, the United Provinces in northern Europe, Prussia, the Ottoman Empire, and Russia. Detailed strategic elements come into play, whether you're fighting in the heart of Europe, warding off Mamluk horsemen in the middle east, or working to capture the wealth of India. Beyond all this, for the first time in Total War history, the continent of North America is an open field of play that portrays the unique strategic problems encountered by the founding fathers during the revolutionary war.Dynamic 3D Naval Battles and Forces of NatureTotal War's signature 3D battle scenes are paired with a new graphics engine and improved technology, allowing war and conquest to take on an even more realistic feel. Advanced landscape and flora systems add both realism and depth to the world stage, while dynamic weather consistently threatens to throw a wrench in your attack plans.Whether you're coordinating platoon firing or supporting a defensive square formation, the musket and the cannon take center stage as newly developed implements of war. And they're not just for use on land. Real-time naval battle set on dramatic seascapes help shape the balance of power and determine the scope of your Empire, and they're rendered in the same impressive 3D as battles on land. You may find yourself directing a vast fleet through intricate maneuvers, controlling the helm of a single tall ship, or grappling to the enemy's boat and dictating the course of hand-to-hand combat on deck.New Multiplayer ActionAdditional updates to the Total War model include a multiplayer component that provides player rankings for competitive commanders, leagues and ladders, and a selection of entirely new modes of game play.
summary: Great Strategy Game, Steam is the only thing hurting it
reviewText: Empire: Total War is the next enry into the Total War series.So far I am really enjoying where this game is going.You get a Great Campaign mode that spans the whole map and you also get a Road to Independance Mode which is sort of a tutorial and mode completely played in the Americas.If you are a fan of the Civilization series and needed a little more OOMPH from these types of games, Total War sets the bar. For one, just like all other games in the TW series, it uses real global maps (it always bugged me that the Civ games never did this) and this time instead of all of you rservice building being built within you cities, they are built nearby and some should be garrisoned.The diplomacy screen is a little more robust this time around but another and big addition to the TW series is the tech tree.What made or broke your nation in the Civ series was your technology and TW is taking this play right out of the playbook.As far as the diplomacy screens, you really have to know who is tied into who because going to war with one nation could trigger at least 2 or 3 other of their allies to come fight against you.  I experienced that the first night I decided to Fight france and in less than an hr, Sweden was annihilated, HAHA!If you have played any other games in this series, you already know what to expect and what to do but there are new nuances such as field promotions and the ability to get new soldiers right to you instead of having them rcreated at your site of creation. The sea battles are most fun because you have more control over ship to ship battles. One hint I will recommend is when fighting even if out numbered, it's best to get 2 or 3 ships to gang up on one and sometimes it will help even the odds, what's even more cool is you can now board a ship and take it over!So, is this game fun?But of course it is and it's not too resource hungry.My only biggest gripe is because it's a Steam product is that it takes forever and a day to install on your machine but at least once it is installed, you can run it without the disk.The buggest caveat however is, if you aren't logged in, you can't play it!!!!I highly recommend this game to those who have enjoyed the TW series and strategy games in particular The game is taking steps that Civ needs to take and pretty soon I can see the TW series possibly carving out it's own niche of strategy gamers who want more realistic play.This game makes me wonder how much longer will it be before we see a modern era (WWII or Viet nam anyone) startegy game of this vein? Or heaven forbid a TW game/Company of Heroes hybrid!  LOLHere is to wishful thinking!In the meantime, pick this up and play it and yes, there are a few annoying bugs like soldiers not always following commands or the such but you can't deny this is so far the best to come about since Rome TW.
